
A careless developer used two Blum integers to generate their RSA keys. Can you recover the flag from the flawed encryption? Ciphertext: 718236238686430889720552701687023672500065916416108056955268949073706263092392979354242197717121887566882943769868690014471127975025812032169165726868250


The flag format is flag{...}
n=10679800295572531256604664548061291814147248210275017274422141328070194088707586597775685118390839318529531206854774629964282679341255149372671551061271673, e=35837413602119110963547678344705536069926379750747215327503829983116826249595472209689262793202636454403140652416185324476449180801656582554911496949939
The lower 104 bits of p are: 6086793741963743257320486224291309067


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{gry0t95q}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 718236238686430889720552701687023672500065916416108056955268949073706263092392979354242197717121887566882943769868690014471127975025812032169165726868250
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=10679800295572531256604664548061291814147248210275017274422141328070194088707586597775685118390839318529531206854774629964282679341255149372671551061271673, e=35837413602119110963547678344705536069926379750747215327503829983116826249595472209689262793202636454403140652416185324476449180801656582554911496949939
The lower 104 bits of p are: 6086793741963743257320486224291309067
